p: The role of anaesthesiology in the COVID-19 response reflects the legacy of these pioneers. Just as the polio epidemics drew on anaesthesiologists from operating theatres for cardiorespiratory support, so has the COVID-19 pandemic. The co-localisation of specifically trained staff, once translated to ICUs, is now reflected in the COVID-19 floors of general medicine. Geographic consolidation of COVID-19 cases is beneficial both for infection control and for training in COVID-19 care. Whilst proper training is essential to better patient outcomes, we must also address the pathophysiology of COVID-19. We have just begun to comprehend the multisystem consequences of its characteristic endothelial injury, spanning from acute respiratory failure to hypercoagulability.
